Award.AwardTitle: Molecular Programming: Bottom-Up Fabrication of Multi-Element Compounds with Precisely-Defined Structure and Composition
Award.AbstractNarration:
With the support from the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program of the Division of Materials Research, Prof. Javier Vela and his group at Iowa State University investigate new "bottom-up" chemical reactivity approaches to control the composition, microstructure and properties of multi-element solid-state compounds. The specific aims of this project are to tune the reactivity of cationic molecular precursors for precise incorporation of transition metal dopants into Cu2ZnSnS4 (CZTS) and to tune the reactivity of phosphide molecular precursors for controlling the composition and degree of phase segregation in metal phosphosulfides.

By enabling the fabrication of complex functional materials, this project has potential broad impacts on other research areas such as renewable energy generation, conversion and storage, magnetic data storage, and catalysis. The educational portion of this project builds on a successful collaboration with Prof. Hua-Jun Fan and his students at Prairie View A&M University (PVAMU), a Historically Black University, and seeks to broaden participation by recruiting and training a diverse scientific workforce. Prof. Fan, a computational chemist, uses computations to guide the development of molecular precursors. The Vela group hosts one PVAMU undergraduate student for eight-to-ten weeks each summer for the three-year duration of the project. Through this project, PVAMU students learn about the synthesis and characterization of solid-state materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Complex solid-state materials made of multiple elements are at the forefront of emerging energy conversion technologies including photovoltaics (solar to power), photocatalysis (solar to fuel), thermoelectrics (power from heat), and fuel cells. However, our ability to synthesize and process such complex materials was, until recently, very limited. Traditional synthetic methods suffer from extensive formation of composition gradients, resulting in uncontrollable phase segregation. In the research portion of this grant, we investigated fundamentally new and controllable solution phase syntheses of multiple element compounds. In a first aim, we discovered that axial composition gradients and phase segregation regulate the aspect ratio of semiconducting nanorods made of four different elements. We learned to modify such “quaternary” materials with a noble metal such as gold in order to produce efficient photocatalytic heterostructures; we also learned to precisely incorporate magnetic, divalent transition metal dopants such as manganese, cobalt and nickel into their structure by tuning the reactivity of cationic molecular precursors. Because the quaternary material we used is made of Earth abundant, widely distributed and largely biocompatible elements such as copper, zinc, tin and sulfur, the resulting materials are useful in devising greener technologies for energy conversion and magnetic data storage. In a second research aim, we made significant progress toward the controllable synthesis of phosphide, sulfide, and mixed phospho-sulfide materials. Specifically, we screened multiple families of tertiary phosphine-chalcogenide molecular precursors and studied their bond energetics from calculations. We also studied the interplay between the bonding in a family of organophosphite molecular precursors and their reactivity toward nickel sources to selectively produce specific nickel and nickel phosphide nanophases.

Having a working scale of chemical reactivities for cationic and anionic (chalcogenide, pnictide) precursors will obviate the need for time-consuming testing of several different reaction conditions or precursors at random as was, until recently, commonly practiced in the field of solution-phase material synthesis. Thus, this research has lead to vertical, rather than incremental, improvements in the synthesis of technologically relevant materials. More generally, this research has positively impacted the field of controllable fabrication of multi-element compounds, allowing synthetic solid-state chemists and material scientists to fabricate and discover complex functional materials for applications in renewable energy generation, conversion and storage, magnetic data storage, and catalysis.

The educational portion of this proposal worked to broaden participation by recruiting and training a diverse scientific workforce. Building on a long established and successful collaboration with Prof. Hua-Jun Fan, a computational chemist, and his students at Prairie View A&M University, a Historically Black College and University (HBCU), the Vela group hosted a total of three Prairie View undergraduates at Iowa State University during the three summers between 2013–2015. This educational component was intimately linked to the research portion of the grant. Fan used computations to support the development of molecular precursors, while the students learned about and supported the synthesis and characterization of solid-state materials. In this way, we contributed to fulfilling the National Science Foundation's mission of advancing basic research and education while addressing major societal challenges such as the national needs for sustainability.
